title: For Sale:  NIB -- Beowulf - Alexander Arms .50 caliber FDE DE AR15 M4
postcontent:
Reduced. 

New, Unfired -- The Beowulf "Thumper" ... I ordered this from Alexander Arms and it finally showed up.  Have not had time to fire it so might just get my money out of it and pass it on to someone has time to shoot it.   You see it still has the AA factory inspection tags attached to the barrel.

What you see is what you get.   it is an upgraded AA .50 Beowulf upper with a threaded barrel and the bad-ass tank baffle everyone wants; looks great and cuts recoil.

I put a single point attachment ring and the throat of the lower and added a nice single-point sling.  I added the grips on the front and the bi-pod pistol grip and the front ... all mounted to MagPul rails.  I even put an extra rail on the top right for a flashlight (its out of the way there) if you get to where you want one.   This has FDE or tan MagPul furniture throughout and all mounted on a PSA multi lower.  For optics, I put on a 3-9x42 NcStar scope and I like the scope a little higher, so I added a UTG 1/2 inch riser rail ... all with quick disconnect attachment bars.  (If you like MagPul pop-up sights, I have a pair and would switch the scope for the MagPul set.)  I also added an ambidextrous BCM Gun Fighter charging handle.

You can see that I added 100s in gear to the basic Beowulf in order to outfit this properly ... ready to use.

I will throw in a hunting-legal 4-round magazine and a larger (10 round I think) mag to get you started.

Separately, I also have some AA Wulf ammo that I can help you because no one local carries it ... it must be mail ordered.  I can make you a fair deal on ammo if it helps.

Prefer FTF and cash but will ship via my FFL at costs.  Local ... VA ID, 21+, and BoS paperwork are non-negotiable.

So ... Let's make a deal.

title: For Sale/Trade:  Llama 1911 XV111A .22
postcontent: I have a Llama micro 1911 .22 for sale/trade. I've looked around and there are not many of these around at all. I believe this model to be a XV111A. It takes down just like a 1911 and it has both a grip safety and thumb safety the gun will not fire if the mag is not in which is another safety feature. There is also railing/ribs on top of the slide. The barell is threaded so it can accept attachments and so forth. Sights are adjustable. It comes with 1 mag that holds 8. The grips are made of a hard brown plastic with black streaks going through it, they look quite nice so I didnt have them replaced. Bluing is 95% and it was made in 1972 imported by stoeger. This gun is made of high quality pieces and guns made by Llama in the '60s-'70s were considered to be the best of Llama. This would make a great carry pistol or a nice piece to a Spanish collection. It comes with 300 rounds of Remington Viper. Due to the fact these are hard to find the price is firm.

title: For Sale:  Russian AK Saiga 7.62x39 Pig Buster
location: NW Military Wurzbach, San Antonio, Texas
postcontent:
I have a Russian Saiga AK 47 74 7.62x39 for sale.  It has an over the top rail mount with rear peep sight and an inexpensive 4 power scope mounted on it.  I set this up to hunt and shoot pigs.  I was always a fan of the SKS and the 7.62x39 for a pig gun.  The Saiga is a major step up from an SKS.  You have all of the reliability of an AK and the handy feel of a carbine for those who don't like the all out assault look and feel.  The Saigas also have the integral side rail in case you want to use a side mounted optic.  These make great truck guns although this one was never treated like one.  The Saiga is all Russian made with a chrome lined, cold hammer forged barrel and a unique to the Saiga bolt hold open feature.  These rifles are the ultimate in reliability.

This one comes with rail mount, scope, original sight blade, sling, factory 10 round magazine, and a 30 round SGM USA made magazine.

I am asking 650 for this lightly used Saiga.

title: For Sale:  '28 Thompson Felt bolt oilers (2) NOS - nice!
location: White Bear Lake area, Minneapolis / St. Paul, Minnesota
postcontent:
Here are two (2) brand new Thompson felt bolt/blish lock oilers that fit in the back end of a '28 Thompson receiver and keep the bolt and internals lubricated.
Some of the West Hurley guns came without these and if you have a GI gun you know these get pretty gummy after awhile. Trying to clean them leaves you with felt that is expanded by cleaning agents (the felt gets all "puffed up"!) and tends to cause a bit of drag on the bolt after cleaning. Once these are FUBAR the only thing you can do is replace them.

I have these extras left over from some trading I did a few years ago (bought a mess of Russian parts kits and extra parts) and won't use them all. so am selling off the extras. 
IF you need one or two for your '28 Thompson, here they are.

They are going for 25-40 bucks, plus shipping when you can find them....mine are reasonably priced at just $20 each, and I'll ship conus in a small USPS Priority flat rate box for just 6 bucks more.
AND IF you want both of them, I'd take $40 shipped to you conus in a small USPS flat rate box.....a pretty darn good deal and one you shouldn't refuse!

Pics are here:

http://tinypic.com/a/3c1s6/2

But you better act fast as these will be snapped up quickly.....the Russian parts are almost dried up and there won't be any more

title: For Sale:  1943 Remington Rand M1911 A1 (Original)
postcontent:
This is what I know about the gun. Its an original 1943 Remington-Rand M 1911 A1 US Army Issue. (Only a few blood spots) According to the serial number this gun was shipped in April of 1943. It is stamped with "FJA" inspector's mark. FJA are the initials of Frank J. Atwood, inspector of ordnance. The "P" proof mark is located near the magazine release and on top of the slide, in front of the rear sight. Cross cannons ordnance mark on the right rear of the frame, to the right of the hammer pin. "UNITED STATES PROPERTY" over the serial number with "M1911A1 U.S. ARMY" to the right of the slide stop pin. Also has the G marking on top of the frame next to the disconnector and P proof mark on top of the slide, in front of the rear sight. HS marked barrel. HS is the marking of High Standard.

This gun is all original, and a wartime piece, as you can tell by the blood spots on the slide and grip. It also comes with original U.S. marked Military issued Holster. This gun still functions perfect, and feeds regular hard ball ammo without fail. A great collector piece for any WWII collection. 1250$ cash FIRM.... They are going for much more than that and this is my bottom cash price. Its a fair amount.

I have many pictures if you want more. FTF in tulsa area only.. Email if interested. email or text 918-four02-zero854

title: For Sale:  WWII ERA SPRINGFIELD M1 GARAND 30-06 RIFLE 1945
postcontent: HERE IS A SPRINGFIELD M1 GARAND CHAMBERED IN 30-06. ACCORDING TO THE SERIAL NUMBER, THE RIFLE WAS MANUFACTURED IN MARCH OF 1945. THE VARIOUS NUMBER STAMPS ON THE RIFLE ARE NOT MATCHING. THE FRONT OF THE PISTOL GRIP IS STAMPED WITH A CIRCLED "P". ON THE LEFT SIDE OF THE STOCK UNDER THE RECEIVER, THE INSPECTION STAMP IS INK STAMPED "S.A." OVER "GAW". THE ORDINANCE WHEEL IS NEXT TO THE INSPECTION STAMP. (S. A. / G.A.W. (Springfield Armory / George A. Woody). Even though George A. Woody died in August 1944, his inspection stamps remained in the Stamp Racks until March of 1945. Other stamps used on the stocks were the circled 'P' proof mark (with serifs) on the pistol grip, and the Ordnance Wheel with Crossed Cannons. The wheel was .437" in diameter.) THERE IS A CLEANING KIT IN THE BUTT. IT COMES WITH THE 4 AMMO LOADING CLIPS. THE WOOD STOCK IS IN GOOD CONDITION WITHOUT ANY CRACKS, JUST TYPICAL SCRATCHES AND WEAR SUITABLE TO ITS AGE AND PURPOSE. THE BARREL STILL RETAINS 80% OF THE ORIGINAL BLUING. THERE IS A SIGNIFICANT AMOUNT OF PITTING ON THE LEFT SIDE OF THE RECEIVER. THIS RIFLE IS FULLY FUNCTIONAL AND IS READY TO SHOOT.

postcontent:
Undoubtedly the BEST magazine you can buy for your VEPR 12.  This is an all steel construction magazine, even the follower (which is a last round hold open). I am selling a portion of my milsurp collection.  From left to right: 

1. 1934 Izhevsk Hex receiver Mosin Nagant 91-30- Excellent condition, perfect bore, one of the nicest 91-30s I've seen- all numbers matching, comes with bayonet -$200-Sold

2. Remington made M1917 in pristine original arsenal condition.  This rifle was made in April of 1918.  Chambered in 30-06.  It was rebarreled by the US government in 1944.  Remington made 1917s are twice as rare as Eddystone mades.   Bore is bright and shinny.  Good shooter.  I have never seen one nicer than this one.  It is gorgeous.- $750- please do your homework on this if you're interested.  Look at CURRENT listings for Remington made 1917s.  They are going for much higher than this and not in this condition. title: For Sale:  AR500 body armor urban go plate carrier with trauma plates
postcontent:
The Urban Go Plate Carrier is the most cost effective complete and ready to go plate carrier package on the market that offers rifle threat protection. Our Urban Go package includes (2) AR500 Armor® Level III  10” x 12” body armor plates. We put our survivalist mentality to work and came up with the essentials required for scenarios that require quick rifle threat protection, creating an armor system that is ready to go at a moment's notice.

The Urban Go Carrier Package is ideal for home protection and emergency situations where rifle threat protection may be necessary. The open side design with a quick release buckles unfastened allows the Urban Go Plate Carrier to be quickly tossed over a single shoulder and worn over any existing gear or body armor. Front access shoulder mounted quick release buckles allow rapid removal compared to plate carriers that utilize a cummerbund. Fast into action, fast out of action. Due to a cummerbund-less design the Urban Go Carrier is not intended to be used with side body armor plates.

title: For Sale:  Sino-Soviet SKS Rifle + Hunting Magazine & "Tacticool" package
postcontent:
*JUST REACTIVATED! (Unfortunately last sale fell through)

This Jianshe Factory 26 Type 56 SKS rifle is a 7.63x39 semi-auto rifle recently imported by Inter Ordnance of Palm Bay, FL.  IO has had quite a few of them in varying conditions after the Sino-Soviet connection was made in the 80s and 90s and is still 100% valid.

"Sino-Soviet" is an early model SKS produced by China using surplus Russian parts under Russian supervision using a mix of domestic Chinese and Russian supplied components (thus the Russian blade-type bayonet instead of a spike bayonet on a Chinese rifle). The sino-soviet ones were actually built by the Russian technicians themselves as a model/training for the first 10,000 Chinese before turning over production fully to them (then longer numbers and Chinese characters began to be used to mark the rifles). A sino-soviet is a first year production chinese rifle made with surplus parts marked with an arsenal /26\ stamp. 4-6 digit serial number preceded by two cyrillic letters.  Lack of a /26\ (or any arsenal) stamp was not necessarily unusual with the flood of SKSs hastily assembled and imported prior to the ban in the 90's.  

The sino's are the most highly sought after because they were the ones the Russians built to teach the Chinese how to mass-produce them.  Crisp-breaking triggers, chromed-lined barrels, and long-lasting accuracy are the markers of this awesome carbine.  The chromed-out barrel on this rifle is pristine and still looks brand-spankin' new!  
---> SEE PIC OF 2 x 5 SHOT STRINGS FROM THE HUNTING MAGAZINE USING IRON SIGHTS AT 100 YARDS TO HIT THE LITTLE 5-POINT TARGET IN THE TOP LEFT CORNER OF QUALIFICATION TARGETS!  AND THAT WAS WITH WAL-MART TUL-AMMO!
YOU WILL BE HARD-PRESSED TO FIND ANOTHER SKS THAT CAN DO THIS!!!

You couldn’t want a more rugged and reliable hunting gun; in Siberia Russians still use them to take Moose and Elk.  In addition to the standard 10-round magazine, this rifle also includes a 5-round magazine legal for hunting in all states except PA and Delaware.  I dropped a 160lbs whitetail doe with it last year at about 80 yards (Hornady SST double-lung shot) and it only went 10 yards before it dropped. 

Before I understood what a Sino-Soviet was I was going to “tacticool” this rifle out over time as a project gun, but being a C&R guy at heart I just couldn’t do it.  I have all the tacticool stuff included (but not attached) including:

- UTG dust cover with top and side mount Picatinny tri-rail
- OEM Steel Universal Design SKS Rifle Ejected Brass Shell Deflector Scope Protector Shield
- Williams Fire Sight SKS Rifle Front Sight 
- BSA Red-Dot sight

-Asking $450 OBO for the whole package (Rifle, hunting magazine, "tacticool" accessories)
